I'll take the Flying Spaghetti Monster, and you can explain how your God managed to kill Cain's descendants so dead during the Flood that they were still around when the Bible was written. (Genesis 4:17-22) Presumably they evolved gills, and then de-evolved them afterwards. In a suitably miraculous manner. And you can't prove they didn't. Oh, wait, it says in Genesis 7:21 that every man on earth died. But, aha! It doesn't say anything about the women! So the pregnant women turned into mermaids during the flood, and back into women later, and had their children several months after that. But only among Cain's descendants, because we know that all the other nations are descended from Noah's sons. See how easy I'm making this for you?
 
 Or you can explain the evolution of Adam's descendants to shorter and shorter lifetimes. 
 
 Or how the animals that fit into on the ark evolved into the tens of millions of species we have today in only 3,500 years or so, and got from the Middle East to Australia, the Americas, and Antarctica (penguins, anyway). Given that the Flood occurred in the year 2,500 or so in the Jewish calendar. Let's see, 300 cubits by 50 cubits by 30 cubits, if a cubit is about half a meter, comes to 55,000 cubic meters or so, of which most is occupied by food for 40 days of rain, and another 150 days of floating around before they came aground on the mountain. Well, seven pairs of elephants would take up at least 300 cubic meters, and then a half year of elephant fodder would take up a few thousand cubic meters, so I don't see how to fit in all the mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, freshwater shellfish, Komodo dragons...Wait a minute. Noah, his wife, his three sons, and his sons' wives, that's only eight people. Who mucked out the stalls and cages and fed the beasties? Particularly the obligate carnivores that can't live on grass or grain? What about the pandas that can only live on bamboo from China? What about the koalas that can only live on eucalyptus leaves? OK, so the bamboo and the eucalyptus were growing in the Middle East back then, along with the pandas and the koalas and the wallabies and the platypi, and they all went away all over the earth in clades so that marsupials only live in Australia and America and like that, and there are no lions in Asia or tigers in Africa, and no monkeys in Africa but lots of apes and people. And the pandas went where the bamboo migrated, and the koalas went with the eucalyptus, and so on, even across oceans, like all the different species of Galapagos finches or the dodo. And none of them left any bones along the way.

But the fact of common descent is a backward extrapolation of the evidence around us today, not a forward extrapolation from a belief about what 'must have happened' in the past.

Ok, so, we're slowly getting there as far as the debate resolution goes. It seems as though macro evolution/common descent is the real bone of contention. Something along the lines of:
 
 "Resolved: A hypothesis of shared ancestry for all living creatures is well supported by the available evidence, whereas a hypothesis of special creation of each individual species is not."
 
 Or, if you would prefer to argue the positive, we could try:
 
 "Resolved: A hypothesis of special creation of every individual species is well supported by the available evidence, whereas a hypothesis of shared ancestry is not."
 
 What do you think?

And there isn't an advocate who will accept a contrary advocate as a judge. Judges with conflicts of interest are expected to recuse themselves. Unless they are Republicans, of course. :)
Conflicts of interest arise when a judge has something to gain depending on the decision rendered...something that might sway the judge from a truly fair judgement according to the rules of engagement. Sharing the opinion of one side or the other in a debate is commonplace for debate judges. This does not constitute conflict of interest. Most arguments have two sides. Where the conflict of interest arises is in the judge having access to benefits from the decision such as granting tax relief to a company owned by the judge.
 
 There are no such conflicts of interest in judgement of rhetorical debates for which the outcome is meaningless save the opinion that one side won. Just as a polished debator can defend either side of an issue, a debate judge can have a personal opinion differing from that of the debator he judges to have won. The judge's task is to determine who won the debate, not whether the resolution has been proved.
 
 If at the end of this proposed debate all judges indicate that feindslayer has won, there will be no proclaimations that creationism is factual, just an opinion that feindslayer won the debate.

So far, you've not given one valid criticism of the way I judge or moderate a debate. You have only attacked my personal style of posting and my personal beliefs. Neither of these are relevant to my ability to perform as a judge or moderator.

 
 Yes, I've seen you in operation on other messageboards. Nothing about them left me any confidence about your impartiality on issues you take personally.
 
 
For instance, I judged two debates on evolution. As a Christian, you'd expect that I would have sided with the Creationists in my decision. I didn't. I sided with the person that made the most compelling argument. That happened to be the pro-evolution positions.

 
 Why would you think I'd expect a Christian to side with XXXXXX? You've simply come to a prior conclusion about that particular debate. Many Christians oppose the Creationism cult. Some of them see it as bibliolatry.
 
 
If you truly don't believe that I can't be objective, cite some actual instances in which my objectivity is lacking. In other words, put up or shut up. 

 
 Your posts on the gay rights boards are evidence enough for your lack of objectivity on issues that get to your centre. Homosexuality offends you much more than evolution. That's the only lesson I get from your posts. I do not get the impression you are a dispassionate observer motivated only by objectivity. You are an advocate for your beliefs. They don't happen to include biblical Creationism, so you oppose it.

 You must have lived a sheltered life. Here's an excerpt from a National Parliamentary Debate Association rulebook.
 

  Objective of the debate
 The proposition team must affirm the resolution by presenting and defending a sufficient case for that resolution. The opposition team must oppose the resolution and/or the proposition team's case. If, at the end of the debate, the judge believes that the proposition team has supported and successfully defended the resolution, they will be declared the winner, otherwise the opposition will be declared the winner.

I've heard your claims, but have yet to see one concrete example of my lack of objectivity vis a vis formal debates.

 Yes, well, there's the difference between politicians and lawyers on the one hand, and scientists. We think it's the data that decides an argument, not mere rhetoric or majority opinion. Rhetoric helps, but empty rhetoric is still just empty rhetoric.
 
 Look, I appreciate that some of you regard this as a sort of sport, so don't let me keep you from it, but empty rhetoric is about as jejune as baseball or cricket. I want substance to a debate before I find it interesting. You can't usually get it debating Creationists. There's no science involved, hence no way of settling differences.
